images.caption: Figure 1:LuxDiT is a generative lighting estimation model that predicts high-quality HDR environment maps from visual input. It produces accurate lighting while preserving scene semantics, enabling realistic virtual object insertion under diverse conditions.

Figure 2:Method Overview.Given an input image or videoùêà\mathbf{I}, LuxDiT predicts an environment mapùêÑ\mathbf{E}as two tone-mapped representations,ùêÑldr\mathbf{E}_{\text{ldr}}andùêÑlog\mathbf{E}_{\text{log}}, guided by a directional mapùêÑdir\mathbf{E}_{\text{dir}}. Environment maps are encoded with a VAE, and the resulting latents are concatenated and jointly processed with visual input by a DiT. The outputsùêÑldr\mathbf{E}_{\text{ldr}}andùêÑlog\mathbf{E}_{\text{log}}are decoded and fused by a lightweight MLP to reconstruct the final HDR panorama.
Figure 3:Qualitative comparison with baseline methods on three benchmark datasets.
Figure 4:Qualitative comparison of virtual object insertion.
Figure 5:Qualitative comparison of video lighting estimation.
Figure 6:The two tone-mapping curves used to generate the LDR images. The 128 dot points along the curve are evenly spaced along[0,1][0,1]LDR value range.
Figure 6:The two tone-mapping curves used to generate the LDR images. The 128 dot points along the curve are evenly spaced along[0,1][0,1]LDR value range.
Figure 7:The histogram of the 99.9-th percentile intensity of all HDR environment maps in our training set.
Figure 8:Randomly sampled example images from our synthetic rendering data.
Figure 9:Visual results on array-of-spheres protocol.
Figure 10:Visual results on Cube++ dataset. We show the rendered two white cube faces, mirror ball, and matte silver ball from our method and DiffusionLight for visual comparison.

Figure 11:Lighting estimation from the NeRF synthetic objects.
We use the estimated lighting from different methods to re-render the original NeRF Blender scenes.
Figure 12:Lighting estimation from the masked real objects from Objects with Lighting.

Figure 13:Model design ablation and LoRA scale exploration.
The ‚ÄúModel Ablation‚Äù column shows the results of our two model design variants: 1) channel concatenation and 2) training without synthetic rendering data. The ‚ÄúLoRA Scale Exploration‚Äù columns show the visual results of our model with different LoRA scales.
Figure 14:Lighting estimation from input images with varying camera FOV.
Figure 15:Lighting estimation from input images with varying camera elevation.
Figure 16:LoRA scale exploration on synthetic foreground scenes.
Figure 17:Additional qualitative results on Laval Indoor dataset.
Figure 18:Additional qualitative results on Laval Outdoor dataset.
Figure 19:Additional qualitative results on Poly Haven dataset.
Figure 20:Additional virtual object insertion on Poly Haven perspective crops.
Figure 21:Additional virtual object insertion on Waymo driving scenes.
